chapter.title: Resident Sojourners
chapter.subtitle: גרם תושבם - Gerim Toshvim
chapter.para: Gerim toshvim is the plural form of ger toshav. Ger toshav

2 Samuel 15:19-21
"Then said the king to Ittai the Gittite, Wherefore goest thou also with us? return to thy place, and abide with the king: for thou art a stranger, and also an exile. Whereas thou camest but yesterday, should I this day make thee go up and down with us? seeing I go whither I may, return thou, and take back thy brethren: mercy and truth be with thee. And Ittai answered the king, and said, As the LORD liveth, and as my lord the king liveth, surely in what place my lord the king shall be, whether in death or life, even there also will thy servant be. And David said to Ittai, Go and pass over. And Ittai the Gittite passed over, and all his men, and all the little ones that were with him. And all the country wept with a loud voice, and all the people passed over: the king also himself passed over the brook Kidron, and all the people passed over, toward the way of the wilderness." - 2 Samuel 15:19-23 KJV is talking about the acceptance process of the nochri to a ger toshav.

sidebar.para: mekablin of the ger toshav: Mekablin means acceptance. When someone accepts you into their fraternity, into their city walls, or into their country as a citizen, they mekablin you. You perform an oath to a constitution or some creed so that you and the other party are on the same understanding and expectation. The word mekablin creates a high amount of confusion when it relates to non-Jews and ger toshav in particular. Many, Rabbis included, will say the ger toshav does not exist today. However, that is not true. What the R"AMBAM says is that the ger toshav is not mekablin today; not that he doesn't exist. The R"AAVAD on Hilchot Issurei Bi'ah 14:7-8 explains that the ger toshav most certainly does exist today. He is just not mekablin because the Yovel year is not in practice.

sect1.title: Responsa
sect1.para: Statement: The Ger Toshav doesn't exist today
Response: Raavad on Hilchot Issurei Bi'ah 14:7-8
Statement: A ger toshav is still a goy
Response: Hilchot Maachalot Assurot 11:8:"when we say plainly 'goy', we mean an idolator".

Concerning the Issurei Biah 14:7:You say that the ger toshav is a goy even after he swears off idolatry.Using that logic, when Issurei Biah 13:3 says a ger tzedek is a goy as well, you're still able to call him a goy:"When a goy desires to enter into the covenant..."However, a ger tzedek is no longer a goy, lest you say all converts cannot keep shabbat, study Torah, etc. per Hilchot Melachim 10:9 "A goy cannot study Torah...". Following the rule in set theory, a subset follows all the attributes of its superset, so when you call a ger a subset of goy, this cannot be the case.

For instance:set all integers: {1,2,3,4,5,6,..}set even integers: {2,4,6,...}Set "even integers" being a subset of "all integers", and if "all integers" turn pink then "even integers" would turn pink due to inheritance by set theory. Therefore, ger toshav is not a subset of goy. Rather, a ger toshav(a non-idolator) is no longer a goy(idolator). They are not goy(idolator). They are ger(non-idolator).The only way(and I would agree with you) that gerim are subsets, is in the Torah definition of goy, such as bnei Yisrael being a goy kodesh(a holy nation). However, we're not talking in the written Torah term, but rather in the halachic term, as defined by the Rambam, Hilchot Maachalot Assurot 11:8:"when we say plainly 'goy', we mean an idolator". Hilchot Maachalot Assurot 11:8 is true statement. If it is true, the you should read Issurei Biah 14:7 as:"Who is a ger toshav? This is an idolator which accepts upon himself to not serve idolatry, [along] with the other commandments commanded to the children of Noach"This also explains why rabbis refer to ger toshav as "half-converts"(as in Avodah Berurah, Avodah Zarah 64b). They were once idol-worshippers, who accepted not to be.You have not shown my argument to be invalid or false. Standing alone and apart from the rest of Mishneh Torah, your argument for Issurei Biah is valid(which would assume the Torah definition of goy), but coupled with the axiom of Maachalot Assurot 11:8(which assumes the halachic Rambam definition of goy), your argument is not valid.
